We generally should not be creating dbus interfaces that send JSON blobs.  If this is in your own upstream, I guess that is for you to decide if it is appropriate, but I'm not sure why bmcweb would accept this proposal.
So it should work like a dump? A request for creating a file and offloading it separately?

Why can't we specify a DBus interfaces that expose the details you outline below? It sounds like we need several, call them `ServiceEvent`, `FailureIsolationEvent` and `ForcedIsolationEvent` for bikeshed purposes? `bmcweb` can then query these if necessary and package the data up in whatever way we deem appropriate.

yes, I think we can spread this data across D-bus interfaces as needed.
otherwise we can also consider saving this json content in a file and share unix file descriptor as property over D-bus.
ServiceEvent, FailureIsolationEvent, or ForcedIsolationEvent also be returning blob, so what is the difference if it is separate or combined?

I don't follow. We would define them so they don't return blobs, but populate the members appropriately. You start to outline a schema below. This just needs translation into PDI YAML, right? Or am I overlooking something?

What I understood from your suggestion is to add methods to retrieve ServiceEvent etc. is that correct?

The problem is that each of these sections can grow based on the number of failures and forced de-configurations so the size won't be fixed for that data part.

But if planning to make calls for each service action from BMCWeb, that will be too many calls, right?

In legacy systems, there was just one call that returned a blob of XML with all these data and which can grow to several KBs

> What I understood from your suggestion is to add methods to retrieve ServiceEvent etc. is that correct?

No. I was suggesting you define several DBus interfaces with members that directly expose the data. No methods required.

> The problem is that each of these sections can grow based on the number of failures and forced de-configurations so the size won't be fixed for that data part.

Can you be more precise here with respect to the number of failures and forced deconfigurations to which you're referring? Surely these are each for separate parts, or multiple distinct types of event on one part? If so, we can continue with my suggestion of representing the data by defining appropriate DBus interfaces with members that expose the data directly.

> But if planning to make calls for each service action from BMCWeb, that will be too many calls, right?
>
> In legacy systems, there was just one call that returned a blob of XML with all these data and which can grow to several KBs

How many calls are too many calls? I wouldn't try to optimise yet - given my queries above I don't think the problem has been stated precisely enough to allow that.

These are the possible members to expose

1. log entries with a special flag set to indicate that failure is important
2. HW Isolation entries 
3. Forced deconfigurations
4. FCO number and policies

Respective services expose 1 and 2, and settings expose 4
but to model 3, all the deconfigurable units need to be modeled by some service.

But even after all these are available as dbus, we need a service to capture it and put it in a JSON file, right?

> But even after all these are available as dbus, we need a service to capture it and put it in a JSON file, right?

I don't see how we get to that, no, besides a bit of a hand-wave that of "we need to do JSON if we're doing Redfish". But even then, it's not clear why some process other than bmcweb has to be generating JSON blobs. After reading the document again, I think it lacks any description of how nag hooks into the redfish data model and how we get the nag data out. I think perhaps we need to start there at the top and work our way to the bottom (where I was proposing the DBus interfaces above) rather than starting at the bottom and work our way up.

What's requesting this data? How is it doing it? Can you provide example `curl` interactions with (potentially yet-to-be-implemented) redfish endpoints to describe what you had in mind?
Getting rid of new redfish methods for retrieving the data since the users are ready to accept it as part of the dump.
okay, so the only way a client gets this data is a bmc dump? So if someone wanted this list of service actions due, they generate a bmc dump?

> Getting rid of new redfish methods for retrieving the data since the users are ready to accept it as part of the dump.

This behaviour is subverting the review process and I don't accept it.

From my understanding of Gunnar's feedback there's no reason this should be in `designs/oem/ibm`, much less exploiting some unusual dump type: There's an opportunity here to provide a solution that is of broad use to the whole community.

Reviewers work under the assumption that you're making an honest attempt to arrive at consensus, and at times this means adjusting *your* position to align with the feedback. In the event that it's the reviewer who's position needs to be adjusted, you need to provide a reasoned argument in the document (not just reponses via review comments) to support that.

Trust is the currency of open source projects. Proposing a design point and then subverting the reviewers by shifting the goalposts based on some internal agreement doesn't motivate anyone to continue reviewing your work. The perception that results here is that you're not interested in driving consensus on a broadly useful solution for the community, rather your interest is to push a minimal-effort, short-term hack that gives us on-going maintenance concerns through product-centric design.

You need to be comfortable with accepting changes to the design-point that require you to work outside your comfort zone. People are here both externally and internally to support you through that so long as you choose to put in the effort.

In my opinion, if you don't feel comfortable that, or with driving community consensus, then we need to find someone else who can champion this proposal.
The idea was already there in the alternate design
Right, but it's unclear why what appears to be the right design is marked as an alternative. Why is that?
Shall we keep this as an oem design for immediate requirements and gradually move to a generic design that the community can accept?

No. I don't think it's helpful to have the community carry documents that bear no benefit to it. As I understand it this design point exists is due to time constraints. The functionality is not intrinsically IBM-specific.

I don't see any reason for the community to carry documents for such circumstances. 

I *do* see benefit in the community carrying documents for functionality that is *currently* IBM-specific because the *functionality* is IBM-specific. It may be the case that in the future other companies encounter similar requirements, in which case we can broaden the scope of the existing document to suit others.

But given that's not the circumstance we have here, if we need this specific design documented, IMO IBM should fork openbmc/docs into ibm-openbmc/docs and stick it there.
